title-group.article-title: Population-Level Health Effects of Involuntary Displacement of People Experiencing Unsheltered Homelessness Who Inject Drugs in US Cities
title-group.alt-title: Health Effects of Involuntary Displacement of Homeless Individuals Who Inject Drugs
Health Effects of Involuntary Displacement of Homeless Individuals Who Inject Drugs

author-notes.p: Author Contributions: Drs Barocas and Mosites had full access to all of the data in the study and take responsibility for the integrity of the data and the accuracy of the data analysis.
Concept and design: Barocas, Nall, Axelrath, Pladsen, Boyer, Kral, Savinkina, Bien, Linas, Mosites.

Drafting of the manuscript: Barocas, Nall, Axelrath, Pladsen, Boyer, Goldshear, Linas, Mosites.

Critical revision of the manuscript for important intellectual content: Barocas, Nall, Axelrath, Pladsen, Boyer, Kral, Meehan, Savinkina, Peery, Bien, Agnew-Brune, Chiang, Linas, Gonsalves, Bluthenthal, Mosites.
Statistical analysis: Barocas, Nall, Chiang, Linas, Mosites.
Administrative, technical, or material support: Barocas, Nall, Pladsen, Boyer, Meehan, Savinkina, Peery, Agnew-Brune, Gonsalves, Bluthenthal, Mosites.

Conflict of Interest Disclosures: Dr Barocas reported receiving grants from the National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA) during the conduct of the study and consulting fees from eMed outside the submitted work. Ms Nall reported receiving grants from NIDA during the conduct of the study. Dr Kral reported receiving grants from National Institutes of Health during the conduct of the study. Dr Linas reported receiving grants from NIDA and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention during the conduct of the study. No other disclosures were reported.

Funding/Support: This work was supported by grants K01DA051684 (Dr Barocas and Ms Nall); DP2DA051864 (Dr Barocas); DP2DA049282 and 5R37DA015612 (Dr. Gonsalves); R01DA038965, F31DA054763, and R01DA046049 (Drs Kral, Bluthenthal, and Chiang and Mr. Goldshear); and R01DA046527 (Dr Linas) from the National Institute on Drug Abuse. This study was funded by grants from the National Institute on Drug Abuse.

Role of the Funder/Sponsor: The National Institute on Drug Abuse had no role in the design and conduct of the study; collection, management, analysis, and interpretation of the data; preparation, review, or approval of the manuscript; and decision to submit the manuscript for publication.
The NHBS Study Group: The members of the NHBS Study Group appear in Supplement 2.
Disclaimer: The findings and conclusions in this report are those of the authors and do not represent the official position of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

related-article.article-title: Involuntary Displacements-Making a Bad Situation Worse.
Mental Health and Substance Use Among Homeless Adolescents in the US
Taking Medicine to the Streets to Care for Those Who Live There.
New Federal Plan to Reduce Homelessness by 25% by 2025 Includes Health Care as Part of the Solution.
Reimagining Institutionalization and a Continuum of Care for People Experiencing Homelessness and Mental Illness.

sec.title: Question
sec.p: What are the long-term health effects of involuntary displacement of people experiencing homelessness who inject drugs in US cities?

sec.title: Findings
sec.p: This simulation modeling study of 23 US cities projects that involuntary displacement of people experiencing homelessness may yield substantial increases in morbidity and mortality over a 10-year period. Involuntary displacement is estimated to worsen overdose and hospitalizations, decrease initiations of medications for opioid use disorder, and contribute to deaths among people experiencing homelessness who inject drugs.

sec.title: Meaning
sec.p: Ceasing involuntary displacement of people experiencing homelessness may mitigate some health-related harms associated with homelessness.

sec.title: Importance
sec.p: At least 500 000 people in the US experience homelessness nightly. More than 30% of people experiencing homelessness also have a substance use disorder. Involuntary displacement is a common practice in responding to unsheltered people experiencing homelessness. Understanding the health implications of displacement (eg, “sweeps,” “clearings,” “cleanups”) is important, especially as they relate to key substance use disorder outcomes.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: To estimate the long-term health effects of involuntary displacement of people experiencing homelessness who inject drugs in 23 US cities.

sec.title: Design, Setting, and Participants
sec.p: A closed cohort microsimulation model that simulates the natural history of injection drug use and health outcomes among people experiencing homelessness who inject drugs in 23 US cities. The model was populated with city-level data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s National HIV Behavioral Surveillance system and published data to make representative cohorts of people experiencing homelessness who inject drugs in those cities.

sec.title: Main Outcomes and Measures
sec.p: Projected outcomes included overdose mortality, serious injection–related infections and mortality related to serious injection–related infections, hospitalizations, initiations of medications for opioid use disorder, and life-years lived over a 10-year period for 2 scenarios: “no displacement” and “continual involuntary displacement.” The population-attributable fraction of continual displacement to mortality was estimated among this population.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Models estimated between 974 and 2175 additional overdose deaths per 10 000 people experiencing homelessness at 10 years in scenarios in which people experiencing homelessness who inject drugs were continually involuntarily displaced compared with no displacement. Between 611 and 1360 additional people experiencing homelessness who inject drugs per 10 000 people were estimated to be hospitalized with continual involuntary displacement, and there will be an estimated 3140 to 8812 fewer initiations of medications for opioid use disorder per 10 000 people. Continual involuntary displacement may contribute to between 15.6% and 24.4% of additional deaths among unsheltered people experiencing homelessness who inject drugs over a 10-year period.

sec.title: Conclusion and Relevance
sec.p: Involuntary displacement of people experiencing homelessness may substantially increase drug-related morbidity and mortality. These findings have implications for the practice of involuntary displacement, as well as policies such as access to housing and supportive services, that could mitigate these harms.

abstract.p: This modeling study examines the potential long-term health effects of involuntary displacement among unsheltered people experiencing homelessness who inject drugs in 23 US cities.
